page.title: 18GRYCE HALL
page.content: Lord Savile lives in Gryce Hall which is a very old house with gargoyles on the walls. Some words are carved in wood over the main door and an ancient statue of a king is set into the wall outside the gate. Although Gryce Hall is large it does not attract attention because it is hidden away in the countryside, surrounded by trees. In response to two letters written to the Lord Savile, he rang us and gave us more information.He said that Gryce Hall was a combination of two cottages, with a barn in the middle converted to a drawing room. He bought it in 1946 and moved there in 1947. Altogether there are about twenty rooms and his favourite is his study. There are no ghosts. Gryce Hall stands in fifty-two acres. Two acres are gardened and fifty acres are used for farming.
